awd_titl_txt: Optimal Pulse Design in Quantum Control
awd_abstract_narration:
The capability to precisely control the dynamics of quantum systems constitutes a significant step in the advancement of quantum science and technology. State-of-the-art quantum technology can be used to trap and experiment with individual atoms (quantum optics), image brains and hearts (magnetic resonance imaging), generate structural and dynamical information of biological macromolecules (nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy), and process information and computation (quantum information and computation). All of these applications are enabled by the application of a single electromagnetic pulse or multiple pulse sequences. A typical problem is to engineer time-varying pulses that simultaneously steer a large ensemble (e.g., billions) of identical quantum systems from an initial state to a desired target state, or as close as possible, in a permissible amount of time. Such pulse design tasks are challenging because individual quantum systems in an ensemble have slightly different dynamics, such as different frequencies, but they need to be controlled by the use of a common control input. This project will develop a unified control-theoretic framework for systematically and effectively design pulses that optimally control the time evolution of quantum systems. This highly transdisciplinary research will not only result in innovative and significant contributions to systems theory and control engineering, but also generate promising contributions to biochemistry and medical physics. For example, this research will enhance resolution in medical imaging for precise medical diagnosis. The project will also support new initiatives to promote interdisciplinary education for students, in particular for those from traditionally underserved populations through the creation of summer research opportunities for students from local high schools in the city of St. Louis, MO.

By bridging ensemble systems theory with geometry and computational optimal control, general and versatile frameworks for quantum control will be formulated. Specifically, a dynamic mapping between nonlinear quantum spin systems and linear harmonic oscillators under optimal forcing will be constructed, which enables the derivation of undiscovered analytical broadband pulses, and an intuitive and elegant geometric connection of the evolution of a quantum spin ensemble with a helix on the Frenet frame will be established. In addition, an iterative algorithm based on the singular value decomposition and a universal optimization procedure integrating multidimensional pseudospectral discretizations and constraint partitioning techniques for designing unconstrained and constrained optimal pulses will be devised. In collaboration with experimental quantum control groups at different institutions in the United States and overseas, the developed methods will be employed to design practical pulses for protein NMR spectroscopy and MRI, as well as low-complexity pulses for portable medical imaging devices. These pulses will be experimentally realized and verified.

por.por_cntn:
State-of-the-art quantum technologies can be used to trap and experiment with individual atoms (quantum optics), image brains (magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)), and generate structural and dynamical information of biological macromolecules (nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy). All of these applications involve properly manipulating collective dynamic behavior, more specifically engineering excitation profiles, in a large quantum ensemble. A canonical way to enable these applications is through the design and application of time-varying electromagnetic pulses (controls) that are broadcast to the systems at the population level, and inhomogeneities across the entire population of quantum systems, let alone its tremendous scale, form a bottleneck for control-theoretic analysis and design. This project develops a principled control-theoretic framework for establishing analyltical and computational tools to systematically design pulses that optimally control the time evolution of quantum systems and meet the practical criteria. 

By bridging ensemble systems theory with tools from differential geometry and computational optimal control, general and versatile frameworks for quantum control have been formulated. This highly interdisciplinary project has elucidated enabling theory and computational algorithms for designing optimal quantum pulses in basic science and clinical applications. Specifically, a dynamic relation between nonlinear quantum spin systems and linear harmonic oscillators under optimal forcing was revealed, which enabled the derivation of analytical broadband pulses. Novel computational algorithms for optimal pulse design were developed, including an optimization-free iterative method for solving optimal control problems involving a quantum ensemble and an integrated method combining non-harmonic Fourier analysis with alternating optimization techniques for synthesizing optimal broadband and selective quantum pulses. The developed methods can be directly employed to design practical pulses for protein NMR spectroscopy and MRI, as well as low-complexity pulses for portable medical imaging devices. The project outcomes enabled a unified systems-theoretic framework for devising optimal quantum pulses, and, further, included a set of formal quantum control methods that may be readily implementable in a wide range of quantum technologies. 

This project substantially advances our understanding of and capability to engineer complex quantum dynamics, and contributes to computational optimal control, ensemble systems theory, quantum physics, structural biology, and radiology by investigating nonconventional control engineering problems related to quantum pulse design. Advanced methods for optimal quantum control may potentially lead to innovative techniques for clinical medicine, such as MRI, and facilitate improved design strategies for other quantum technologies such as quantum computing and quantum information processing. The project also enhances the infrastructure for research and education across these disciplines by merging the fields of control theory, dynamical systems and computational engineering. The research products and outcomes have been disseminated broadly to these scientific communities through publications, presentations at conferences, invited lectures and colloquia, and distributed software to engage researchers around the world in this exciting interdisciplinary domain. 

Multiple workshops, including the Midwest Workshop on Control and Game Theory and the ACC Workshop on Advanced Data-driven Methods for Complex Systems Analysis and Controls were organized. Special and invited sessions on the topics of Control, Estimation and Identification of Quantum Systems were organized in major international conferences in the Control Systems Society. Efforts were made by the PI to attract under-represented minorities and women to our research program. An independent study course on `Control, Computation, and Learning of Population Systems' was established by the PI. The outreach effort was continued made to engage the general public and pre-college K-12 students in scientific research through Science Outreach Programs at Washington University in St. Louis.
